results.title: Defence of Milak = Memories of Milak
results.creator_credit: Keith Johnston and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Keith Johnston was a member of Btroop 2/10th commando squadron and served in Northern New Guinea during World War II. During the battle in Milak village, he was stuck in a pit with two others for over five days.
results.description: Keith Johnston was a member of Btroop 2/10th commando squadron and served in Northern New Guinea during World War II. During the battle in Milak village, he was stuck in a pit with two others for over five days.
description_for_label: Keith Johnston was a member of Btroop 2/10th commando squadron and served in Northern New Guinea during World War II. During the battle in Milak village, he was stuck in a pit with two others for over five days.

results.title: Decidedly out of this world
results.creator_credit: Joan Rossi and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: In 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Britain was at war with Germany and that, as a result, Australia is at war with Germany. Joan Rossi talks about how she joined the army in 1941 and subsequent training, her work as a Syphon Officer, moving to Brisbane and tells of how she decoded the sinking of the ship Centaur. Post war, Joan still helped out at RAAF, helping other women find work before finding her own job and settling into post war life
results.description: In 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Britain was at war with Germany and that, as a result, Australia is at war with Germany. Joan Rossi talks about how she joined the army in 1941 and subsequent training, her work as a Syphon Officer, moving to Brisbane and tells of how she decoded the sinking of the ship Centaur. Post war, Joan still helped out at RAAF, helping other women find work before finding her own job and settling into post war life
description_for_label: In 1939, Prime Minister Menzies announced that Britain was at war with Germany and that, as a result, Australia is at war with Germany. Joan Rossi talks about how she joined the army in 1941 and subsequent training, her work as a Syphon Officer, moving to Brisbane and tells of how she decoded the sinking of the ship Centaur. Post war, Joan still helped out at RAAF, helping other women find work before finding her own job and settling into post war life

results.title: Fancy that
results.creator_credit: Joan Johnstone and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: When Joan showed a photo of her new boyfriend to her mother, her mother remarked that he looked a lot like Selby Adams, a British pen friend she wrote to in World War I. Joan served in the Australian Women’s Army Service during World War II and, as a result of that service, was able to re-unite her mother with her pen friend from Britain. An amazing coincidence
results.description: When Joan showed a photo of her new boyfriend to her mother, her mother remarked that he looked a lot like Selby Adams, a British pen friend she wrote to in World War I. Joan served in the Australian Women’s Army Service during World War II and, as a result of that service, was able to re-unite her mother with her pen friend from Britain. An amazing coincidence
description_for_label: When Joan showed a photo of her new boyfriend to her mother, her mother remarked that he looked a lot like Selby Adams, a British pen friend she wrote to in World War I. Joan served in the Australian Women’s Army Service during World War II and, as a result of that service, was able to re-unite her mother with her pen friend from Britain. An amazing coincidence

results.title: All the days of my life
results.creator_credit: Joan Johnstone and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: In 1941, the Australian Women’s Army Services was formed and Joan chose to join the AWAS to fight for Australia. Her dad was in the army as was missing in action. Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.
results.description: In 1941, the Australian Women’s Army Services was formed and Joan chose to join the AWAS to fight for Australia. Her dad was in the army as was missing in action. Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.
description_for_label: In 1941, the Australian Women’s Army Services was formed and Joan chose to join the AWAS to fight for Australia. Her dad was in the army as was missing in action. Joan was transferred to work on Salt, the official army publication. It was called Salt because salt was so essential to life. Joan’s story is about her service, her marriage and her work with Salt.

results.title: War, tears and memories
results.creator_credit: Jean Parry and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Jean’s greatest memory was the Battle of Alemein. She remembers the noise and the booming of the guns and the flood of patients needing attention. Serving as a army nurse during World War II, Jean recalls some of her most memorable times during the war, as well as her life in Melbourne, growing up with four brothers in Oakleigh and how 17 members of her family attended the Anzac Day march in 2009.
results.description: Jean’s greatest memory was the Battle of Alemein. She remembers the noise and the booming of the guns and the flood of patients needing attention. Serving as a army nurse during World War II, Jean recalls some of her most memorable times during the war, as well as her life in Melbourne, growing up with four brothers in Oakleigh and how 17 members of her family attended the Anzac Day march in 2009.

Serving as a army nurse during World War II, Jean recalls some of her most memorable times during the war, as well as her life in Melbourne, growing up with four brothers in Oakleigh and how 17 members of her family attended the Anzac Day march in 2009.

results.title: Battle for Australia
results.creator_credit: Jean King and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: I have vivid memories of watching the Army march along Swanston Street, fit and tanned with heads held high, wearing the famous slouch hat. Jean King’s husband was a navy salvage diver during World War II, and she shares her experiences of being the wife of a war veteran as well as the toll the war took on families and the returned after the war
results.description: I have vivid memories of watching the Army march along Swanston Street, fit and tanned with heads held high, wearing the famous slouch hat. Jean King’s husband was a navy salvage diver during World War II, and she shares her experiences of being the wife of a war veteran as well as the toll the war took on families and the returned after the war

results.title: When quiet came
results.creator_credit: Bill Flowers and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Bill Flowers tells his story of how he was captured by the Japanese and sent to Changi as a POW. His tale is one of survival. Bill was in the 2/9th Field Ambulance during World War II. This digital story was recorded as part of In Our Words : Stories from Victorian Veterans digital storytelling workshop.
results.description: Bill Flowers tells his story of how he was captured by the Japanese and sent to Changi as a POW. His tale is one of survival. Bill was in the 2/9th Field Ambulance during World War II. This digital story was recorded as part of In Our Words : Stories from Victorian Veterans digital storytelling workshop.

Bill was in the 2/9th Field Ambulance during World War II. This digital story was recorded as part of In Our Words : Stories from Victorian Veterans digital storytelling workshop.

results.title: Life and learning
results.brief_description: Tim Kanoa expresses his culture through dance. He is proud of his Aboriginality and has been living and learning from the day he was born. This digital story was created in partnership with the Koorie heritage Trust.
